poem:
Title: "Ballet in Borrowed December"

Through the frost-embroidered panes, pirouettes blossom
as tiny dancers, flitting like frosted moths.
Laughter murmurs beneath the silken hum of Tchaikovsky's ghosts.
Children, bewitched in their Sunday best,
Elder hands holding tight to the ephemeral spectacle.
Time is a ballet, and December, a swift and glimmering dancer,
Waltzing us towards another year's uncertain grace.
prompt: You are the poet Ocean Vuong. You woke up this morning feeling exuberant. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Nutcracker review – English National Ballet and the Royal Ballet’s annual festive face-off The Nutcracker is ballet’s pantomime. Villains, heroines and magic. An audience full of festive cheer. Lots of little girls and boys in their party best on a family treat, grandmas and grandads in tow. A mood of high anticipation and enjoyment. Some of Tchaikovsky’s most beautiful and hummable tunes rising from the orchestra. For the ballet companies, it’s a seasonal banker". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
